content:
This is a pretty hard clash.
Just got it and won with 50% (7/8 clashers got 0%).
Figuring out how the head works is hard to debug since you never see the whole right answer until your answer is almost correct (IDE corrects only the first wrong line).
Reverse might actually be easier than other modes for this one, as trying to understand the statement takes a lot of time and it's still a bit confusing.

The "s/2+1" part in particular is confusing, since you don't define the indexing as 1-indexed but it's needed to be clear since for s=2, "s/2+1"=2 saying that the "w" should be in the 2nd column of the output (1-indexed).
I overlooked this and tried to code it in 0-indexed with the same formula and couldn't make even cases work in the end.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle! It's literally an easy and fun challenge for the CoC.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's original and pretty easy to understand.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: fun short clash, would be very fun in any mode. i would change some of the validators to be different, but in this case, hardcoding is harder than doing it the honest way, so it does not really matter.

All sections
* Please format "\", "/" and "w" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Constraints section
* Please remove the constraint. Constraints refer to the scope of the cases that the players expect to see.

* Please mention the range of values of [[s]].

* Please mention that [[s]] is always an odd number.

Cases
* Tests and validators should be different. Please revise the cases.

Thanks.
Thank you for all your advice ! I made all the changes but I was only able to change one validator because I'm stuck with the textbox beyond 11. Hope it's not a problem for the validation!
**Thank you for the feedback ! I made the necessary changes so that [[s]] can be even or odd. This allowed me to create different validators than tests! I let you watch my changes.
It's not a good idea to have tests being the same as validators. Maybe you can introduce even-length snakes, with clarification of how the head position is determined in such cases?
Thank you for the feedback ! I made the necessary changes so that [[s]] can be positive or negative. This allowed me to create different validators than tests! I let you watch my changes.
Positive or negative? Do you mean odd or even?
Yes, sorry, that's a mistake! The change is made.
